Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
Indeed, one must measure as he would be measured. Allah the Exalted has said: **"Woe to the defrauders [al-mutaffifin]â€”those who, when they take a measure from people, take in full, but when they measure or weigh for them, they give less."** (83:1-3). And one is not saved from this except by giving more when he gives and taking less when he takes, for true justice [al-'adl al-haqiqi] is scarcely conceivable. So let him seek the clear evidence of increase and decrease. For whoever exacts his right in its entirety is on the verge of transgressing it. And some of them would say: "I will not purchase Woe from Allah for a single grain." So when he would take, he would decrease by half a grain, and when he would give, he would increase by a grain. And he would say: "Woe to him who sells for a single grain a Paradise whose width is the heavens and the earth. And how great is the loss of him who sells bliss [tuba] for woe [wil]!" And they were excessive in guarding against this and its like because they are injustices [mazalim] from which repentance is not possible, for the owners of the grains are not known so that one could gather them and fulfill their rights. And for that reason, when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, purchased something, he said to the weigher as he was weighing its price: "Weigh, and give more." A hadith states: He said to the weigher, "Weigh, and give more." Narrated by the compilers of the Sunan and al-Hakim from the hadith of Suwayd ibn Qays. Al-Tirmidhi said: "Hasan Sahih." And al-Hakim said: "Sahih according to the conditions of Muslim." And Fudayl looked at his son as he was washing a dinar, intending to exchange it and remove its blackening and purify it so that its weight would not increase because of that, and he said: "O my son, your doing this is better than two Hajj pilgrimages and twenty 'Umrahs." And some of the predecessors said: "I am amazed at the merchant and the sellerâ€”how can he be saved? He weighs and swears by day, and sleeps by night." And Sulayman, peace be upon him, said to his son: "O my son, just as a grain enters between two stones, so does a sin enter between the two parties in a transaction." And one of the righteous prayed over an effeminate man, and it was said to him: "He was a sinner [fasiq]." So he remained silent. It was repeated to him, and he said: "It is as if you are telling me he was the owner of two scales: he would give with one and take with the other." He indicated by this that his sin was an injustice between him and Allah the Exalted. And this is from the injustices against servants [mazalim al-'ibad], and being lax and forgiving in it is more remote. And the severity in the matter of the scale is great, and salvation from it is achieved by a grain and half a grain. And in the recitation of 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him: **"Do not transgress in the measure, and establish the weight with fairness, and do not diminish the measure"**â€”meaning the tongue of the scale, for decrease and increase appear by its inclination. And in summary, everyone who demands full justice for himself from others, even in a word, but does not give justice in like manner, he falls under the saying of Allah the Exalted: **"Woe to the defraudersâ€”those who, when they take a measure from people, take in full..."** (83:1-3). For the prohibition of that in what is measured is not because it is something measured, but because it is a quantified matter in which justice and fairness have been abandoned. Thus, it applies to all actions. So the owner of the scale is in danger of the Woe, and every legally responsible person is an owner of scales in his actions, his words, and his thoughts. So the Woe is for him if he deviates from justice [al-'adl] and inclines away from uprightness [al-istiqamah]. And were it not for the difficulty and near-impossibility of this, His saying, the Exalted, would not have come: **"And there is none of you but will come to it. This is upon your Lord an inevitability decreed."** (19:71). So no servant is freeâ€”who is not protected from sinâ€”from inclining away from uprightness, except that the degrees of inclination vary with a great variation. Therefore, the duration of their stay in the Fire varies until the time of deliverance, so that some remain only for the duration of fulfilling an oath, and some remain for a thousand and thousands of years. So we ask Allah the Exalted to bring us close to uprightness and justice, for adhering firmly to the straight path [al-sirat al-mustaqim] without any deviation from it is not something to be hoped for, for it is finer than a hair and sharper than a sword. And were it not for that, the one upright upon it would not be able to cross the Sirat stretched over the midst of the Fire, whose description is that it is finer than a hair and sharper than a sword. And according to one's uprightness on this straight path, the servant is lightened on the Day of Resurrection upon the Sirat. And everyone who mixes food with dirt or other, then measures it, he is from the defrauders in measuring. And every butcher who weighs bone with meat in a manner not customary, he is from the defrauders in weighing. And judge by this all other estimations, even in the cubit measurement undertaken by the cloth merchant. For when he buys, he releases the cloth at the time of measuring and does not stretch it fully, and when he sells it, he stretches it in the measurement to make it appear more.

And woe to him in the explicit text of the Book of Allah (the Quran) where He said: 'Woe to the defrauders (Al-Mutaffifin) who, when they take by measure from people, take in full, but when they measure to them or weigh for them, they give less.' And everyone who seeks from justice more than what his soul (Nafs) permits is included under the implication of this verse. The origin of deficiency in covering faults (Satr Al-Awrah) or striving to uncover them is the hidden disease in the inner self (Al-Batin), which is rancor (Al-Hiqd) and envy (Al-Hasad). For the rancorous envier fills his inner self (Batin) with wickedness but restrains it within his inner self (Batin) and conceals it and does not manifest it as long as he does not find an opportunity for it. And when he finds an opportunity, the bond is dissolved and modesty (Al-Haya) is lifted, and the inner self (Al-Batin) seeps with its hidden wickedness. And whenever the inner self (Al-Batin) contains rancor and envy, then severance is preferable.

Then contemplate the crowding of the creatures and their gathering until the inhabitants of the seven heavens and the seven earths crowded upon the standing place (al-Mawqif) from angels, jinn, humans, devils, beasts, predators, and birds. The sun shone upon them, and its heat had multiplied and changed from what it was in lightness of its matter. Then it was brought near to the heads of the worlds like the distance of two bow-lengths, so there remained on the earth no shade except the shade of the Lord of the Worlds (Rabb al-'Alamin), and none could take shade in it except the ones brought near (al-Muqarrabun). So between one taking shade under the Throne (al-'Arsh) and one exposed to the sun's heat, which has melted him with its heat, and his distress and grief have intensified from its blaze. Then the creatures pushed one another and some pushed others due to the severity of the crowding and the difference in feet, and added to it is the severity of shame and modesty (al-Haya') from exposure and shrinking back at the presentation before the Compeller of the sky. So the blaze of the sun, the heat of breaths, and the burning of the hearts (al-Qulub) with the fire of modesty (al-Haya') and fear (al-Khawf) gathered, so sweat flowed from the root of every hair until it streamed on the plain of the Resurrection (al-Qiyamah). Then it rose on their bodies according to the measure of their stations (al-Manzilat) with Allah. For some, the sweat reached his knees; for some, his waist; for some, to the lobe of his ears; and for some, he almost drowned in it. Ibn 'Umar said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'The Day when the people will stand before the Lord of the Worlds (Yawma yaqumu al-nasu li-Rabb al-'Alamin) until one of them drowns in his sweat up to half his ears.'

A day when the creatures will stand with their eyes staring, their hearts (Qalb) shattered, not speaking nor having their affairs looked into; they will stand for three hundred years, not eating a meal in it nor drinking a drink in it, nor finding in it a breath of breeze. So contemplate in the length of this day and the intensity of waiting in it, so that waiting for patience from sins in your short life becomes light for you.

Indeed, it is the sealing [tab'] and it is the stain [rayn]. Allah the Exalted says: "No! Rather, what they have earned has stained their hearts [qulub]." (83:14). And He, the Mighty and Majestic, says: "If We willed, We could strike them for their sins and seal [natba'u] their hearts [qulub], and they would not hear." (7:100). Thus, He linked the absence of hearing to the sealing [tab'] due to sins, just as He linked hearing to God-consciousness [taqwa], saying: "And be conscious of God and listen." (5:108), and "And be conscious of God, and God will teach you." (2:282). Whenever sins accumulate, the heart [qalb] is sealed [yutba'u], and at that point the heart [qalb] becomes blind to perceiving the truth [haqq] and the rectitude of religion [din], and it belittles the matter of the Hereafter [Akhira] and magnifies the matter of the world [dunya], and its concern becomes restricted to it. So when its ear is struck with the matter of the Hereafter [Akhira] and the perils within it, it enters one ear and exits the other, and it does not settle in the heart [qalb] nor move it to repentance [tawba] and recovery. Those have despaired of the Hereafter [Akhira] as the disbelievers despair of the companions of the graves. This is the meaning of the heart's [qalb] blackening by sins, as declared by the Quran and the Sunnah. Maymun ibn Mihran said: "When a servant commits a sin, a black spot is imprinted on his heart [qalb]. If he desists and repents, it is polished. But if he returns, it is increased in him until it covers his heart [qalb]â€”that is the stain [rayn]." And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The heart [qalb] of the believer is bare, with a shining lamp within it. And the heart [qalb] of the disbeliever is black, inverted." Obedience to God, glorified is He, by opposing desires is a polisher for the heart [qalb], and His disobediences blacken it. So whoever inclines to disobediences, his heart [qalb] blackens. And whoever follows a bad deed with a good deed and erases its trace, his heart [qalb] is not darkened, but its light [nur] diminishes, like a mirror into which one breathes, then it is wiped, then one breathes, then it is wipedâ€”it is not free from cloudiness. And he, peace be upon him, said: "Hearts [qulub] are of four kinds: a bare heart [qalb] with a shining lamp within itâ€”that is the heart [qalb] of the believer; a black, inverted heart [qalb]â€”that is the heart [qalb] of the disbeliever; a wrapped heart [qalb], bound upon its coveringâ€”that is the heart [qalb] of the hypocrite; and a layered heart [qalb] containing faith [iman] and hypocrisy [nifaq]â€”the likeness of faith [iman] within it is like a plant nourished by pure water, and the likeness of hypocrisy [nifaq] within it is like an ulcer nourished by pus and blood. Whichever of the two nourishments prevails over him, he is judged by it." And in a narration: "It takes him away." Allah the Exalted says: "Indeed, those who are conscious of God [muttaqun]â€”when an impulse from Satan touches them, they remember [dhikr] and at once they have insight [basar]." (7:201). He informed that the polishing [jala'] of the heart [qalb] and its insight [basar] are attained through remembrance [dhikr], and that none can attain it except those who are conscious [ittaqaw]. So God-consciousness [taqwa] is the gate to remembrance [dhikr], and remembrance [dhikr] is the gate to unveiling [kashf], and unveiling [kashf] is the gate to the greatest success [fawz al-akbar], which is success in meeting Allah the Exalted.

And among them is that he be compassionate toward all the servants of Allah, merciful to them, severe against all the enemies of Allah and against everyone who commits something that He dislikes, as Allah the Exalted said: "Severe against the disbelievers, merciful among themselves." So look at this example: For the child, if burdened with a thing, does not leave it at all, and if it is taken from him, he has no occupation except crying and shouting until it is returned to him. Whoever disputes him in it, he hates him, and whoever gives it to him, he loves him. As for the tiger, he cannot control himself when angry until he reaches such intensity of anger that he destroys himself. These are the signs of love (muhabbah). And as Allah the Exalted said: "A reward matching." That is, the reward matched their deeds, so the pure was met with the pure from the drink, and the mixed was met with the mixed, and the mixing of every drink is according to what preceded of mixing in his love and his deeds: "So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it - And Allah does not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves - Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight. So extract the Fear (Khauf) from your Heart (Qalb) through prolonged contemplation of the terrors of Hellfire, and extract the Hope (Rajaa) through prolonged contemplation of the abiding Bliss (Na'eem) promised to the people of the Gardens. Drive your Soul (Nafs) with the whip of Fear and guide it with the reins of Hope to the Straight Path (Sirat al-Mustaqeem), for by that you will attain the great dominion and be saved from the painful punishment. So contemplate the people of Paradise, and in their faces is the radiance of Bliss (Nadhrat an-Na'eem). They are given to drink of a sealed pure wine, sitting on thrones of red ruby, in tents of moist white pearl, therein spreads of green brocade, reclining on couches set up on the banks of rivers flowing with wine and honey, surrounded by youths and boys, adorned with wide-eyed maidens of beautiful goodness, as if they were ruby and coral. No man has touched them before them, nor jinn. They walk in the degrees of the Gardens; when one of them sways in her walk, seventy thousand boys carry her flanks. Upon her are fine white silks that dazzle the eyes, crowned with tiaras studded with pearl and coral, coquettish, fragrant, secure from old age and misery, secluded in the tents, in palaces of ruby built amidst the meadows of the Gardens, with restrained glances. Then they are served, and upon them, with cups and ewers and a cup from a flowing spring, white, a delight to the drinkers. And there circulate upon them servants and boys like hidden pearls, as a reward for what they used to do, in a secure station, in Gardens and springs, in Gardens and a river, in a seat of truth near an Omnipotent Sovereign. They look therein at the face of the Noble King, and the radiance of Bliss (Nadhrat an-Na'eem) has shone in their faces. No fatigue touches them, nor humiliation, but they are honored servants, and with various gifts from their Lord they are attended. They are in what their Souls (Anfus) desire, abiding forever; they fear not therein, nor do they grieve, and they are secure from the doubt of death.
